concise_definition: adv. 也, 太, 过于

definitions.explanation_en: Used to indicate that something is also true for another person or thing; equivalent to 'also' or 'as well'.
definitions.explanation_cn: 用于表示某事对另一个人或事物也同样成立，相当于‘也’或‘同样’。
definitions.example_en: I love pizza, and my brother loves it too.
definitions.example_cn: 我喜欢披萨，我哥哥也喜欢。

definitions.explanation_en: Used to indicate an excessive degree or amount; synonymous with 'excessively' or 'more than is desirable'.
definitions.explanation_cn: 用于表示程度或数量过高，超出合理或期望的范围，相当于‘太’或‘过于’。
definitions.example_en: The coffee is too hot to drink right now.
definitions.example_cn: 这杯咖啡现在太烫了，没法喝。

definitions.explanation_en: Used in informal speech to emphasize a statement, often with a tone of surprise or resignation; similar to 'as a matter of fact' or 'in fact'.
definitions.explanation_cn: 用于非正式口语中加强语气，常带有惊讶或无奈的语气，类似于‘事实上’或‘其实’。
definitions.example_en: I didn't mean to offend you — I was just trying to help, too.
definitions.example_cn: 我不是故意冒犯你——我其实只是想帮忙而已。

comparison.analysis: “Also” (也) 通常用于句中，语气更正式，位置较固定，常紧跟在动词前或助动词后。而 “too” 更常用于句末，语气更口语化，带有轻微的补充意味。例如：I also like tea. / I like tea too. 两者语义相近，但语用风格不同。
“Very” (非常) 用于加强形容词或副词的程度，但不表示‘过度’或‘多余’，仅强调强度。而 “too” 暗含负面评价，表示‘超过了可接受的限度’。例如：very hot（很热）vs. too hot（太热了，不能接受）。
“Either” (也) 用于否定句中，与 “too” 形成互补。当句子是否定结构时，必须用 “either” 而非 “too”。例如：I don't like coffee. She doesn't like it either. 而 “too” 只用于肯定句。
